name: Connor
comment info:
I notice that there seems to be a clear negative trend in the ages of world leaders, over the past 70 years. In 1950, the average age of world leaders seemed to be around 62, whereas in 2020, it seems to have dropped to around 52.  The spread in ages of world leaders does not seem to have changed though, as the spread appears to be around 20 years above and below the average across all years. Another thing I noticed is that Republican U.S. presidents appear to generally be older than Democrat U.S. presidents, as most of the republican presidents are above the trend line and most democrat presidents are below the trend line in age. 
I wonder why Republican presidents tend to be older than Democrat presidents, and I also wonder if there are distinct differences in ages based on parties for other countries. I wonder what may explain these differences in age based on party affiliation, and if age could somehow be correlated to presidential election winners based on party. I also wonder if the trend line is statistically significant in the model.
This impacts my community and me as it shows that in general, world leaders have been younger and younger over the years, as this could perhaps impact who a candidate may relate to most. 
“Changes in Average Ages of World Leaders Over Time”

I notice that the ages of US Presidents follow a similar trend as the ages of the leaders of foreign nations. name: Moderator Greg
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded.  We had so many great catchy headlines that capture the main ideas of the graphs:  "Our Leaders Are the Grandparents of Nations" by Frank of Milford, Delaware, “Presidents: Old and Experienced, or Young and Innovative?“ by Sam of Academy of Saint Elizabeth, "Are the Older Bolder, or Will They Smolder?" by Bella of USA, "Age Is Just a Number, But Does It Influence the President?" by Sophie of Andover, Massachusetts, and “Are US Presidents Too Old?” by Morgan of Tulsa, Oklahoma.

name: Kaitlin
comment info:
I noticed that Churchill was the oldest in office, while Kennedy was the youngest in office. If Biden were to be elected, he would be the oldest president entering office. I also notice that the majority of democratic presidents fall under the trend line (Truman doesn't), while republican presidents either cross or are past the trend line. Based on the gray arrows, it also seems like the youngest leader of a democratic nation is well below the age of forty, and the oldest leader of a democratic nation well over the age of eighty. 
I wonder why the average age has a downward trend, as shown by the trend line. I wonder how age relates - if at all - to the way that democratic leaders govern their nation. I also wonder whether age affects the nation's views of the president/PM, and if it plays in a role in voting. I wonder how this graph would compare if leaders of non-democratic nations were included. Since elected democrats tend to be younger than elected republicans, I wonder why that is. Is it because conservative and liberal ideals appeal differently between generations? 
This impacts my community because if age correlates to the decisions that leaders make in office, then if affects us, the population that they're governing. Younger candidates will appeal more to younger generations such as Gen Z and millennials and be lost in touch in with older generations such as Gen X and boomers. 
Headline: Is Age Just a Number? The Downward Trend of Age for Democratic Nation Leaders.

name: The Montessori School
comment info:
We are a class of 7th and 8th graders. 
We noticed:
 - A lot of old men
 - Some arrows are longer than others - they seem to match the length of time in office. 
 - There are red (US Republicans), gray (other countries), and blue (U.S. Democrats) arrows.  
 - The trend is between 60-70 years old.  
 - JFK was the youngest. 
 - Biden would be the oldest on the graph if elected. 
 - The average age decreases as time goes by, with the exception of Trump (and possibly Biden)
 - Most of the arrows below the trend line are blue, and most of the arrows above the line are red. 

We wonder:
 - when there will be a female president.
 - why more people over 50 get elected.
 - who the unlabeled arrows represent, and how many countries are represented
 
The impact this has on us and our community is that the President has a lot of influence -  If just old people are president, then new perspectives are never brought to the table and we just keep repeating the same old thing. An older candidate might not be able to connect and empathize with younger people.

Some headlines:
 - The Old and the Older: How the American Presidents' Ages Compare to Other Countries' Leaders
 - Old is the New Young; America Wake Up!
 - Presidency is Reaching a New Age

name: Moderator Sharon
comment info:
Welcome to Wednesday's moderation of “What’s Going On in This Graph?”  

The Presidential election is in six days.  There are so many graphs of polls and the positions of the candidates and their supporters.  Rather than a graph on these aspects of the election, here is a graph about the ages of O.E.C.D. (Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development) world leaders since 1950. Here are a couple words you may want to check for your understanding and use in your response:  gerontocracy, ageism, Baby Boomers, and presidential vs. parliamentary systems.
